bibl.title: Letter from Felipe Carbonell Ponce to Philip Showalter Hench, January 12, 1942

div1.p: Ponce discusses his efforts to establish a memorial at Camp Lazear. He will be meeting with the Cuban President on this matter.

div1.head: Letter from Felipe Carbonell Ponce to Philip Showalter Hench, January 12, 1942
div1.opener:
From Dr Ponce
Habana Lunes 12 de Enero de 1942.
Dr. Phillip S. Hench.
Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
About two weeks ago I received the tenth of December issue of the Mayo
Clinic proceedings. Having found most interesting your article “Conquerors of the
Yellow Fever” I translated it and took it to “Salas Radio Station”.

Headed by Dr. Donald Nelson, a group of American doctors were expected in
Havana at that time for the formation of the Finlay Institute of the Americas.
Thinking this was an appropriate moment Mr. Salas and I decided to inform the President
of the Republic of your article and get his help for making Camp Lazear an international
monument to the medical classes of Cuba and the United States. On the same day that
the President decorated the American doctors, Mr. Salas spoke to him and got his most
enthusiastic approval. The President called Dr. Sergio Garcia Marruz, (acting Minister
of Health and giving him my translation of your article begged of him a speedy study
and information. Dr. G. Marruz found it extremely important and seconded our idea
warmly.

Mr. Salas immediately informed the public over the air and has considered
this scheme his most important transmission.

Last Saturday Salas and I went together to visit Dr. G. Marruz and talked
to him for more than two hours of this subject. He is taking today Monday, this
question to the Council of Ministers, at the Presidents request, to be discussed.
They will try to find the way to solve this problem, and will probably have to send
a message to the Congress to get his approval. This is the actual situation.

As Mr. Pogolotti and John J. Moran were mentioned in your article, I look
for Mr. Pogolotti in the telephone book as soon as Mr. Salas had spoken to the President
and made a date with him at the hospital where I work, to visit Camp Lazear. The next
day Mr. Salas and I had the pleasure of meeting the most kindly Mr. Pogolotti and we
all together visited, first the false site and then the real Camp Lazear at the San
Jose farm. Mr. Pogolotti informed us of your extraordinary interest and work on this
subject. He also gave us Mr. Moran's address and the same afternoon I paid him a
visit. There I also heard many things about you.

According to what I had read in your article, Mrs. Morans and Pogolottis
information and what I already knew personally, I wrote the notes that Dr. G. Marruz
is taking to-day to the Council. I think that the Cuban Government can raise a building
having Camp Lazear in its center, more or less following the sketch you gave to Mr.
Pogolotti.

It is my idea, and I think also the Presidents to make a ceremony at the
dedication of this memorial.

I am looking forward to an interview with the President, and then if this
takes place, I will send you more details about the venture.

I want to give you my ideas about this subject. I understand that the
would be memorial building, should be a monument to the Cuban and American medical
classes. It is my intention not to accept discussions as to whether the monument
should be dedicated to any special person. I have the impression, drawn from your
article that you have the same opinion. I sincerely believe that is the only way
in which we can carry out our idea with success.

I want you to know that my interest in this subject is greatly intensified
by the fact that you are a doctor of the Mayo Clinic that I visited twice, and where
Dr. Fred Rankin removed my thyroid gland years ago with the greatest success.

I hope to receive your opinion and any ideas that you have for this memorial
project as soon as possible.

closer.signed:
Dr. Felipe Carbonell Ponce
San Lazaro 413
Habana, Cuba
closer.seg:
P.S.
I am decidedly against transferring Camp Lazear to any other site.
